elements.content: Combining the chemistry of metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) and covalent organic frameworks (COFs) can bring new opportunities for the design of advanced materials with enhanced tunability and functionality. Herein, we constructed two COFs based on Ni–bis­(dithiolene) units and imine bonds, representing a bridge between traditional MOFs and COFs. The Ni–bis­(dithiolene)­tetrabenzaldehyde as the 4-connected linker was initially synthesized, which was further linked by 4-connected tetra­(aminophenyl)­pyrene (TAP) or 3-connected tris­(aminophenyl)­amine (TAA) linkers into two COFs, namely, Ni-TAP and Ni-TAA. Ni-TAP shows a two-dimensional sql network, while TAA is a twofold interpenetrated framework with an ffc topology. They both exhibit a high Brunauer–Emmett–Teller surface area (324 and 689 m2 g–1 for Ni-TAP and Ni-TAA, respectively), a fairly good conductivity (1.57 × 10–6 and 9.75 × 10–5 S m–1 for Ni-TAP and Ni-TAA, respectively), and high chemical stability (a stable pH window of 1–14 for Ni-TAA). When applied in lithium metal batteries as an intermediate layer for guiding the uniform Li electrodeposition, Ni-TAP and Ni-TAA displayed impressive lithiophilicity and high Li-ion conductivity, enabling the achievement of smooth and dense Li deposition with a clear columnar morphology and stable Li plating/stripping behaviors with high Li utilization, which is anticipated to pave the way to upgrade Li metal anodes for application in high-energy-density battery systems.

Combining
the chemistry of metal–organic frameworks (MOFs)
and covalent organic frameworks (COFs) can bring new opportunities
for the design of advanced materials with enhanced tunability and
functionality. Herein, we constructed two COFs based on Ni–bis­(dithiolene)
units and imine bonds, representing a bridge between traditional MOFs
and COFs. The Ni–bis­(dithiolene)­tetrabenzaldehyde as the 4-connected
linker was initially synthesized, which was further linked by 4-connected
tetra­(aminophenyl)­pyrene (TAP) or 3-connected tris­(aminophenyl)­amine
(TAA) linkers into two COFs, namely, Ni-TAP and Ni-TAA. Ni-TAP shows
a two-dimensional sql network, while TAA is a twofold interpenetrated
framework with an ffc topology. They both exhibit a high Brunauer–Emmett–Teller
surface area (324 and 689 m2 g–1 for
Ni-TAP and Ni-TAA, respectively), a fairly good conductivity (1.57
× 10–6 and 9.75 × 10–5 S m–1 for Ni-TAP and Ni-TAA, respectively), and
high chemical stability (a stable pH window of 1–14 for Ni-TAA).
When applied in lithium metal batteries as an intermediate layer for
guiding the uniform Li electrodeposition, Ni-TAP and Ni-TAA displayed
impressive lithiophilicity and high Li-ion conductivity, enabling
the achievement of smooth and dense Li deposition with a clear columnar
morphology and stable Li plating/stripping behaviors with high Li
utilization, which is anticipated to pave the way to upgrade Li metal
anodes for application in high-energy-density battery systems.

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) and covalent organic frameworks (COFs) are emerging classes of crystalline porous materials with potential applications in gas adsorption/separation, catalysis, biomedicine, energy conversion, and many others. While MOFs are inorganic–organic hydride materials comprising metal ions or clusters bridged by coordinating organic ligands, COFs are organic materials built from strong covalent bonds. As a result of the rich chemistry of both metals and ligands, MOFs show abundant structures and tunable functionalities. However, their practical applications are often hindered by the low chemical stability of coordination bonds. On the other hand, COFs can be more stable than MOFs, but their functions are often limited by the lack of active metal centers. Therefore, incorporating metals into COFs holds high promise in combining the advantages of MOFs and COFs while overcoming their limitations. Usually, organometallic linkers (such as metallosalen, metalloporphyrin, and metallophthalocyanine-based linkers) are used to incorporate metals into COFs, which endow the materials with metal sites for catalysis, sensors, and electrochemical processes. Despite the diversity of metal complexes, the structures of metal centers in COFs are still scarce. Therefore, the design of novel metal-complex building units is vital in the functionalization of COFs for targeted applications.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction
Metal–organic
frameworks (MOFs) and covalent organic
frameworks (COFs) are emerging classes
of crystalline porous materials with potential
applications in gas adsorption/separation, catalysis, biomedicine, energy conversion, and many others. While MOFs are inorganic–organic hydride materials comprising
metal ions or clusters bridged by coordinating organic ligands, COFs
are organic materials built from strong covalent bonds. As a result of the rich chemistry of both metals and ligands, MOFs
show abundant structures and tunable functionalities. However, their practical applications are often hindered by the
low chemical stability of coordination bonds. On the other hand, COFs can be more stable than MOFs, but their functions are often limited by the lack of active metal
centers. Therefore, incorporating metals into COFs holds high promise
in combining the advantages of MOFs and COFs while overcoming their
limitations. Usually, organometallic linkers (such as metallosalen, metalloporphyrin, and metallophthalocyanine-based linkers) are used to incorporate metals into COFs, which endow the materials
with metal sites for catalysis, sensors, and electrochemical processes.
Despite the diversity of metal complexes, the structures of metal
centers in COFs are still scarce. Therefore, the design of novel metal-complex
building units is vital in the functionalization of COFs for targeted
applications.

elements.content: The metal–bis­(dithiolene) moiety is a promising building unit for both MOFs and COFs. Metal–bis­(dithiolene) complexes have rich electrochemical activity, resulting in unique properties in the field of optical, electrical, and magnetic materials. Therefore, it has been widely used in the construction of conductive and electroactive MOFs. For example, two-dimensional MOFs based on Co–bis­(dithiolene) have been synthesized, which exhibit metallic conductivity. Recently, our group incorporated Ni–bis­(dithiolene) centers into carboxylate-based MOFs to catalyze CO2 reduction and glucose oxidation reactions. Nevertheless, metal–bis­(dithiolene) has never been used as a building unit to construct COFs according to our knowledge.

elements.content: Ni–bis­(dithiolene) can be regarded as an inorganic analogue of tetrathiafulvalene (TTF). Notably, TTF has been widely used as a building unit to fabricate COFs for electrical conducting and electrochemical devices. For instance, the two-dimensional (2D) COF built by 2,3,6,7-tetra­(4-formylphenyl) tetrathiafulvalene (TTF-4CHO) and 1,4-phenyldiamine has shown good electrical conductivity in both the powder state (∼10–5 S cm–1) and oriented film (10–3 S cm–1). In addition, connecting TTF-4CHO with a porphyrin linker resulted in a series of COFs showing applications in electrocatalytic CO2 reduction and Li–CO2 batteries. Considering the structural similarity between Ni–bis­(dithiolene) and TTF, we expect to obtain Ni–bis­(dithiolene)-based COFs that are isostructural to TTF-based ones. Taking advantage of the unique electronic structure and redox activity of Ni–bis­(dithiolene) centers, the resulting Ni–bis­(dithiolene)-COFs may represent a combination of a high surface area, good electronic conductivity, and redox activity. These features of Ni–bis­(dithiolene)-COFs are suitable for lithium metal anodes in lithium metal batteries (LMBs).

Ni–bis­(dithiolene) can be regarded as an inorganic analogue
of tetrathiafulvalene (TTF). Notably, TTF has been widely used as
a building unit to fabricate COFs for electrical conducting and electrochemical devices. For instance, the two-dimensional
(2D) COF built by 2,3,6,7-tetra­(4-formylphenyl) tetrathiafulvalene
(TTF-4CHO) and 1,4-phenyldiamine has shown good electrical conductivity
in both the powder state (∼10–5 S cm–1) and oriented film (10–3 S cm–1). In addition, connecting TTF-4CHO with a porphyrin
linker resulted in a series of COFs showing applications in electrocatalytic
CO2 reduction and Li–CO2 batteries. Considering the structural
similarity between Ni–bis­(dithiolene) and TTF, we expect to
obtain Ni–bis­(dithiolene)-based COFs that are isostructural
to TTF-based ones. Taking advantage of the unique electronic structure
and redox activity of Ni–bis­(dithiolene) centers, the resulting
Ni–bis­(dithiolene)-COFs may represent a combination of a high
surface area, good electronic conductivity, and redox activity. These
features of Ni–bis­(dithiolene)-COFs are suitable for lithium
metal anodes in lithium metal batteries (LMBs).

elements.content: Herein, we synthesized two COFs containing Ni–bis­(dithiolene) centers and systematically explored their key role in guiding the uniform Li deposition and improving the electrochemical performances of Li metal anodes in LMBs. To realize this, we initially designed a Ni–bis­(dithiolene)-based linker, namely, Ni­(bded)2 (bded = bis­[1,2-di­(4-formylphenyl)­ethylene-1,2-ditholate]). Subsequently, Ni­(bded)2 was extended by 4-connected tetra­(aminophenyl)­pyrene (TAP) or 3-connected tris­(aminophenyl)­amine (TAA) linkers into Ni-TAP and Ni-TAA, respectively. Ni-TAP and Ni-TAA were further applied as guiding layers on Cu current collectors to realize uniform and efficient Li deposition in LMBs. The assembled Li||Cu half batteries displayed highly stable Li plating/stripping behaviors and significantly enhanced Coulombic efficiencies (CEs) of 99.1% after 220 cycles for Ni-TAA/Cu and 98.5% after 200 cycles for Ni-TAP/Cu at 1.0 mA cm–2 with a capacity of 1.0 mA h cm–2. Furthermore, when various Cu electrodes plated with Li were paired with LiFePO4 (LFP) cathodes, full batteries assembled with Li@Ni-TAA/Cu and Li@Ni-TAP/Cu anodes presented improved Li plating/stripping stability, delivering considerable discharge capacities of 140.3 and 122.3 mA h g–1, respectively, even after 400 cycles at 1.0 C. The impressive electrochemical performances of Ni-TAA and Ni-TAP modified electrodes were attributed to the uniform porosity, superior Li-ion conductivity, redox activity, and lithiophilicity of Ni–bis­(dithiolene)-based COFs.

elements.content: Topological analysis was adopted to guide the rational design of COFs. We initially designed a Ni–bis­(dithiolene)-based linker containing four aldehyde groups, namely, Ni­(bded)2, which can be regarded as a planar 4-connected building unit (b). When combined with another 4-connected planar node, a 2D network with an sql topology is expected (f). Alternatively, by connecting 4-connected planar linkers and 3-connected triangular linkers, a 3D framework structure with an ffc topology can be obtained (g). To realize this design, we chose two amine-based linkers, TAP and TAA, as the 4-connected and 3-connected linkers (a,c), respectively. The imine condensation reaction between Ni­(bded)2 and TAP or TAA gave rise to the expected network structures, namely, Ni-TAP and Ni-TAA (d,e,h,i). It should be noted that the frameworks of Ni-TAP and Ni-TAA are supported by both Ni-dithiolene coordination bonds and imine covalent bonds. In contrast, the coordination bonds in other COFs (e.g., metallosalen, metalloporphyrin, and metallophthalocyanine-based ones) do not require coordination bonds to support the framework.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion
Topological Guided Design of Ni-Bis­(dithiolene)-COFs
Topological analysis was adopted to guide the rational design of
COFs. We initially designed a Ni–bis­(dithiolene)-based
linker containing four aldehyde groups, namely, Ni­(bded)2, which can be regarded as a planar 4-connected building unit (b). When combined
with another 4-connected planar node, a 2D network with an sql topology is expected (f). Alternatively, by connecting 4-connected planar linkers
and 3-connected triangular linkers, a 3D framework structure with
an ffc topology can be obtained (g). To realize
this design, we chose two amine-based linkers, TAP and TAA, as the
4-connected and 3-connected linkers (a,c), respectively. The imine condensation
reaction between Ni­(bded)2 and TAP or TAA gave rise to
the expected network structures, namely, Ni-TAP and Ni-TAA (d,e,h,i). It should
be noted that the frameworks of Ni-TAP and Ni-TAA are supported by
both Ni-dithiolene coordination bonds and imine covalent bonds. In
contrast, the coordination bonds in other COFs (e.g., metallosalen,
metalloporphyrin, and metallophthalocyanine-based ones) do not require
coordination bonds to support the framework.

elements.content: Schematic representation for the design of COFs with Ni–bis­(dithiolene) units. (a–c) Molecular structures and topological representations of Ni­(bded)2 and TAP as a planar 4-connected node and TAA as a 3-connected node. Molecular structures of COFs, denoted as Ni-TAP (d) and Ni-TAA (e), formed from the imine condensation of Ni­(bded)2 and TAP or TAA. Topological representation of the 2D sql and 3D ffc nets for Ni-TAP (f) and Ni-TAA (g). Extended structures of mesoporous 2D Ni-TAP (h) and 3D Ni-TAA (i).

elements.content: Ni-TAP and Ni-TAA were synthesized by reacting Ni­(bded)2 with TAP or TAA in a mixture of n-butanol/o-dichlorobenzene in the presence of acetic acid (6 M) at 120 °C for 3 days, which afforded green microcrystalline solids. Their structures were confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) analysis combined with structural simulations using Materials Studio. Pawley refinements gave a PXRD pattern (red curves) that matched well with the experimental data (black dots), as reflected by their negligible differences (green curve). Ni-TAP shows diffraction peaks at 5.4, 11.5, and 22.9°, which can be attributed to the (101), (004), and (010) facets, respectively (a). Pawley refinement of Ni-TAP based on a P222 orthorhombic space group provided lattice parameters of a = 19.36, b = 3.87, and c = 30.57 Å. This structure adopts a 2D sql net with an eclipsed AA-stacking mode. On the other hand, Ni-TAA exhibits two intense peaks at 4.007 and 6.908° and relatively weak peaks at 7.992, 10.557, 13.840, and 17.427°, corresponding to the (040), (002), (042), (023), (004), and (025) facets, respectively (b). The refinement results of Ni-TAA yielded unit cell parameters of a = 9.08, b = 87.87, and c = 25.51 Å in the Cmcm orthorhombic space group. The structure of Ni-TAA is simulated to be a twofold interpenetrated framework with an ffc topology, which yields a PXRD pattern similar to the experimentally observed pattern. Both Ni-TAP and Ni-TAA refinement results matched the experimental data with good agreement factors (R p = 2.07% and R wp = 2.78% for Ni-TAP; R p = 1.85% and R wp = 2.46% for Ni-TAA).

elements.content: The successful formation of Ni-TAP and Ni-TAA was further verified by Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy. A new peak at 1619 cm–1 was observed for Ni-TAP or Ni-TAA, which is a typical characteristic of the CN bond. The concomitant disappearance of the N–H stretching vibration (3200–3500 cm–1 for TAP or TAA) and the CO stretching vibration [1695 cm–1 for Ni­(bded)2] confirmed the complete conversion of aldehyde and amine groups (c). To estimate the porosity of Ni-TAP and Ni-TAA, nitrogen adsorption/desorption isotherms were obtained at 77 K. Both Ni-TAP and Ni-TAA show type I isotherms, indicating microporous structures. A slight increase of N2 uptake was observed from 0.2 to 1.0 P/P 0 along with open hysteresis loops, which could be attributed to the narrow and nonrigid slit pores formed between COF particles. The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface areas were measured to be 324 and 689 m2 g–1 for Ni-TAP and Ni-TAA, respectively (d). Compared with their TTF-based COF analogues, Ni-TAP and Ni-TAA possess lower BET surface areas, which can be attributed to their high density resulting from NiS4 moieties. Moreover, the twofold interpenetration of Ni-TAA further reduced its porosity. Pore size distributions were further derived from the adsorption isotherms. Ni-TAP shows two pores of 10.0 and 11.4 Å (Figure S6), corresponding to the two tetragonal channels in the structural model (10.4 and 12.0 Å). The pore size of Ni-TAA was calculated to be 9.3 Å, matching well with the cavity formed by two sets of interpenetrated frameworks in the structural model (9.4 Å) (Figure S7). The inclination of isotherms and the slight desorption hysteresis can be related to the presence of mesopores and macropores from the agglomeration of COF particles. To investigate the chemical stability of Ni-TAA, we dispersed Ni-TAA in different aqueous solutions over a wide pH range, including water, basic solutions with a pH value of 14, acid solutions with a pH value of 1, and many solvents (e).

elements.content: Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and transmission electron microscopy images showed that both COFs have small particle sizes (an average particle size of 0.2–0.5 μm), whereas the crystal morphology was ambiguous due to aggregation of smaller crystallites (f,g, S8, and S9). Additionally, the corresponding elemental mapping analysis reveals that S and Ni are uniformly distributed over Ni-TAP and Ni-TAA, suggesting their homogeneous nature. Moreover, both Ni-TAP and Ni-TAA possessed high thermal stability up to 350 °C, as confirmed by thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) (Figures S10 and S11). Ni­(bded)2, Ni-TAP, and Ni-TAA show a comparable Ni 2p3/2 peak at 854.47 eV, indicating that the Ni oxidation state was not changed during the synthesis of COFs (XPS, Figure S12). The ultraviolet/visible diffuse reflectance spectroscopy (UV/vis) of Ni-TAP and Ni-TAA revealed a broad absorption band with the edge at 2000 nm, which is significantly extended compared to Ni­(bded)2 (the absorption band edge at 1400 nm, Figures S13–S15). As revealed by the Tauc plot, the band gaps of Ni-TAP and Ni-TAA are 0.63 and 0.5 eV, respectively (Figure S16). Notably, the electrical conductivities of Ni­(bded)2, Ni-TAP, and Ni-TAA were measured to be 1.38 × 10–4, 1.57 × 10–6, and 9.75 × 10–5 S m–1, respectively (Figures S17–S19 and Table S1).

elements.content: Ni-TAP and Ni-TAA are considered ideal substrates for guiding uniform Li nucleation and regulating Li deposition behaviors. The redox-active Ni–bis­(dithiolene) units not only enhance the electroconductivity but also act as lithiophilic sites to guide uniform Li deposition. The rich imine bonds in Ni-TAA and Ni-TAP can be lithiated, which further regulates Li deposition, as verified by cyclic voltammetry (CV) curves of Li||Cu half cells during the initial stage of Li deposition (Figure S20). This assumption was further confirmed by DFT-calculated Li deposition energies on different sites of COFs (Figure S21), which revealed Ni–bis­(dithiolene) units as the primary Li deposition sites (E ads = −69.09 kJ mol–1) and imine moieties as the secondary sites (E ads = −42.93 kJ mol–1) (Table S2). Moreover, the high porosity and uniform pore size of Ni-TAA and Ni-TAP can enhance the electrolyte wettability of the current collectors (Figure S22), thus favoring the homogeneous distribution of Li-ion flux and fast Li-ion transport. Considering the unique porous structure, conductivity, electrochemical activity, and lithiophilic Ni–bis­(dithiolene) sites, we prepared surface-modified Cu current collectors by coating Ni-TAA and Ni-TAP on the bare Cu surface (Ni-TAA/Cu and Ni-TAP/Cu) to achieve dendrite-free Li deposition behavior and a stable Li plating/stripping process. SEM images and the corresponding EDX elemental mappings showed that the coated Ni-TAA and Ni-TAP were uniformly dispersed on the surface of Cu current collectors and retained their intrinsic morphology (Figures S23–S25).

Li Plating/Stripping Behavior of the COF-Based Current Collector
Ni-TAP and Ni-TAA are considered ideal substrates for guiding uniform
Li nucleation and regulating Li deposition behaviors. The redox-active
Ni–bis­(dithiolene) units not only enhance the electroconductivity
but also act as lithiophilic sites to guide uniform Li deposition. The rich imine bonds in Ni-TAA and Ni-TAP can
be lithiated, which further regulates Li deposition, as verified by
cyclic voltammetry (CV) curves of Li||Cu half cells during the initial
stage of Li deposition (Figure S20). This assumption was further confirmed by DFT-calculated
Li deposition energies on different sites of COFs (Figure S21), which revealed Ni–bis­(dithiolene) units
as the primary Li deposition sites (E
ads = −69.09 kJ mol–1) and imine moieties as
the secondary sites (E
ads = −42.93
kJ mol–1) (Table S2).
Moreover, the high porosity and uniform pore size of Ni-TAA and Ni-TAP
can enhance the electrolyte wettability of the current collectors
(Figure S22), thus favoring the homogeneous
distribution of Li-ion flux and fast Li-ion transport. Considering
the unique porous structure, conductivity, electrochemical activity,
and lithiophilic Ni–bis­(dithiolene) sites, we prepared surface-modified
Cu current collectors by coating Ni-TAA and Ni-TAP on the bare Cu
surface (Ni-TAA/Cu and Ni-TAP/Cu) to achieve dendrite-free Li deposition
behavior and a stable Li plating/stripping process. SEM images and
the corresponding EDX elemental mappings showed that the coated Ni-TAA
and Ni-TAP were uniformly dispersed on the surface of Cu current collectors
and retained their intrinsic morphology (Figures S23–S25).

elements.content: The Li utilization during the repeated Li plating/stripping cycle was tested systematically in Li||Cu half cells based on Ni-TAA/Cu, Ni-TAP/Cu, and bare Cu to corroborate the key role of Ni-TAA and Ni-TAP/Cu in enhancing Li plating/stripping stability. The average CEs during Li plating/stripping were first measured according to Aurbach et al. (a). During 20 cycles, the average CEs were up to 99.03 and 98.87% when using Ni-TAA/Cu and Ni-TAP/Cu, respectively. In comparison, the batteries with bare Cu only showed an average CE of 90.81%. Moreover, compared with the voltage–time curve of bare Cu, the Ni-TAA/Cu and Ni-TAP/Cu electrodes exhibited decreased voltage polarization, especially during 16–20 cycles (b). The CEs of various electrodes were further investigated in the long-term Li plating/stripping cycling process. At a current density of 1.0 mA cm–2 with a capacity of 1.0 mA h cm–2 (c), the batteries based on the bare Cu current collector presented significantly degraded cyclic stability, and a rapidly deteriorating Li utilization efficiency of 75.5% was obtained only after 85 cycles. In contrast, the batteries assembled with Ni-TAA/Cu and Ni-TAP/Cu displayed markedly improved CEs and prolonged cycling lifespans, delivering well-maintained CEs of 99.1% for Ni-TAA/Cu after 220 cycles and 98.5% for Ni-TAP/Cu after 200 cycles. The CEs at a higher current density (2.0 mA cm–2) or with a larger areal specific capacity (2.0 mA h cm–2) were also measured (Figure S26a,b). As expected, the Li||Cu half cells using Ni-TAA/Cu and Ni-TAP/Cu electrodes possessed well-maintained CEs and presented a greatly enhanced cycling lifespan and stability. The above CE testing results fully demonstrated that Ni-TAA and Ni-TAP coated on Cu current collectors could significantly promote a fast Li plating/stripping process, guide uniform Li deposition and finally achieve high Li utilization due to the outstanding advantages of Ni-TAA and Ni-TAP in composition and structure.

elements.content: The accelerated Li-ion migration and reduced energy barrier of Li nucleation could be further proven by comparing mass-transfer overpotentials and nucleation overpotentials of different current collectors at the initial Li plating stage (d). For bare Cu, the mass-transfer overpotential and nucleation overpotential reached 61.4 and 67.6 mV, respectively (Figure S27), which were much higher than those of Ni-TAP/Cu (33.8 and 14.9 mV). When employing the Ni-TAA/Cu electrode, both the mass-transfer overpotential and nucleation overpotential were further reduced, determined to be 25.4 and 14.0 mV, respectively, revealing that the coated Ni-TAA/Cu and Ni-TAP/Cu can dramatically promote the mobility and reduce the plating barrier of Li ions on the electrodes. Moreover, the voltage profiles of Li plating/stripping on Ni-TAA/Cu, Ni-TAP/Cu, and bare Cu current collectors at 1.0 mA cm–2 were examined in detail (Figure S28). Compared with bare Cu, Ni-TAA/Cu and Ni-TAP/Cu displayed efficient Li utilization and nearly overlapped voltage curves with small overpotentials even after 160 cycles. By further comparing the voltage polarizations of the 80th cycle, it was found that Ni-TAA/Cu and Ni-TAP/Cu exhibited ultralow overpotentials of 27.2 and 37.2 mV, respectively, while the overpotential of bare Cu was up to 56.7 mV, convincingly demonstrating that Ni-TAA/Cu and Ni-TAP/Cu played a key role in improving the cycling stability and electrochemical kinetic performance of batteries. Nyquist plots based on Li||Cu half batteries were also conducted to further testify the enhanced charge-transfer kinetics of Ni-TAA/Cu and Ni-TAP/Cu (e,f). From the results summarized in Table S3, both electrolyte resistances and interfacial resistances of the batteries with bare Cu were much higher than those with Ni-TAA/Cu and Ni-TAP/Cu before and after 50 cycles, indicating that faster charge transfer and smaller electrode polarization were achieved with the assistance of Ni-TAA/Cu and Ni-TAP/Cu. Additionally, the testing of CV based on various Li||Cu half batteries further proved the advantages of Ni-TAA/Cu and Ni-TAP/Cu in enhanced Li plating/stripping kinetics (g). Remarkably, the response currents of the batteries with Ni-TAA/Cu and Ni-TAP/Cu increased obviously during Li plating/stripping relative to the bare Cu, corresponding to rapid Li-ion transport and reversible reaction kinetics. To more directly verify the superior Li-ion conductivity of Ni-TAA/Cu and Ni-TAP/Cu, the Li-ion diffusion coefficient (D Li) was measured quantitatively via the galvanostatic intermittent titration technique (GITT), and the test results showed that both Ni-TAP and Ni-TAA possessed high Li-ion diffusion coefficients (Figure S29c,d). Especially, in the early stage of Li deposition corresponding to the high potential range (>1.2 V), the order of magnitude of D Li was up to 10–11 to 10–12, which fully illustrated that Ni-TAP and Ni-TAA were capable of accelerating Li-ion migration, thus achieving fast Li plating/stripping kinetics. The microstructures and chemical bonds of COFs greatly affect the performance of COF electrodes through the following mechanisms. First, the micropores of COF allow the infiltration of the liquid electrolyte and thus enhance the ion conductivity of the COF layer. Second, the micropores of COF could potentially block the large TFSI– anions while allowing the transport of Li+ due to the size effect, which reduced the corrosion of Li metal by the liquid electrolyte and homogenized the Li+ flux, thus achieving a uniform Li deposition. Furthermore, COFs with strong covalent bonds possess superior thermal and electrochemical stability, as confirmed by TGA (Figures S10 and S11) and PXRD (e), which is beneficial to achieving advanced metal host anodes and addressing the volume expansion issue.

elements.content: To more intuitively reveal the effect of Ni-TAA/Cu and Ni-TAP/Cu on the morphology of Li deposition and suppression of Li dendrite growth, the morphology evolution of stripped Li and plated Cu electrodes retrieved from Li||Ni-TAA/Cu, Li||Ni-TAP/Cu, and Li||bare Cu after 50 cycles was investigated by SEM. For the bare Cu with 5.0 mA h of plated Li (Figure S30a–d), numerous holes and cracks on loose and rough surfaces were clearly observed. The magnified SEM image showed that sharp Li dendrites and aggregated dead Li had completely covered the electrode surface. Evidently, the bare Cu suffered from severe electrolyte corrosion, and the structure of the native SEI was completely destroyed after 50 cycles. In sharp contrast, the cycled Ni-TAA/Cu and Ni-TAP/Cu with 5.0 mA h of plated Li presented a smooth and dense surface and realized grain coarsening of Li deposition (∼10 μm in width) with a clear columnar morphology (Figure S30e–l), which could effectively maintain the bulk Li with a continuous electron conducting pathway during the stripping process, thus enabling efficient Li utilization. Cross-section SEM images also proved the considerable effect of Ni-TAA and Ni-TAP guiding layers on regulating uniform Li deposition. Relative to the loose Li deposition with a thickness of more than 70 μm on the bare Cu surface (Figure S31a,b), the plated Li on Ni-TAA/Cu and Ni-TAP/Cu electrodes was much more compact and exhibited obviously decreased thicknesses of 27 and 29 μm, respectively (Figure S31c–f). Significant morphological differences were also observed for the various Li electrodes with 5.0 mA h of stripped Li (Figure S32). The surface of Li metal paired with bare Cu was covered by a large number of dendritic and dead Li, presenting a porous and loose surface morphology (Figure S32a,b). However, for the Li metal paired with Ni-TAA/Cu or Ni-TAP/Cu (Figure S32c–f), the desired columnar morphology with large grain sizes could also be observed, further illustrating that the stable Li plating/stripping process and efficient Li-ion migration were achieved. Furthermore, to verify the well-maintained columnar morphology at higher plating current densities or higher Li plating loadings, we further characterized the surface morphology of various Cu electrodes cycled at 2.0 mA cm–2 with 5.0 mA h of plated Li and 1.0 mA cm–2 with 10.0 mA h of plated Li. When cycled at 2.0 mA cm–2, a smooth and flat Li plating surface with an ideal columnar morphology was still observed for the Ni-TAA/Cu and Ni-TAP/Cu electrodes (Figure S33e–l), while the cycled bare Cu presented a rough and unconsolidated surface with numerous clear Li dendrites (Figure S33a–d). For the higher Li plating loading of 10.0 mA h, the cycled Ni-TAA/Cu and Ni-TAP/Cu electrodes also exhibited an obvious columnar morphology (Figure S34e–l), and the grain sizes were clearly bigger than that displayed at 1.0 mA cm–2 with 5.0 mA h of plated Li (Figure S30e–l), illustrating that Li tended to grow in the horizontal rather than vertical direction, which could effectively avoid the growth of Li dendrites. In conclusion, SEM investigation fully demonstrated that the well-maintained columnar morphology could be obtained with the assistance of Ni-TAA and Ni-TAP guiding layers whether under high plating current densities or high plating load conditions. In addition to the well-maintained columnar morphology, the crystal structure stability of Ni-TAA and Ni-TAP after 10 charge/discharge cycles was also verified by XRD analysis. The characteristic peaks of Ni-TAA [at 4.007 and 6.908° corresponding to (400) and (002) diffractions, respectively] and TAP [at 5.4 and 11.5° corresponding to (101) and (004) diffractions, respectively] were well maintained, confirming the structural intactness of Ni-TAA and Ni-TAP after repeated Li plating/stripping cycles (Figure S35a).

elements.content: To further demonstrate the crucial role of the coated Ni-TAA and Ni-TAP in regulating uniform Li deposition and inhibiting Li dendrite growth, well-designed less Li||less Li symmetric batteries and less Li||LFP full batteries were assembled and tested by employing special less Li anodes. Specifically, 5.0 mA h metallic Li was deposited on Ni-TAA/Cu, Ni-TAP/Cu, and bare Cu current collectors after Li||Cu half cells were cycled for 50 cycles (Figure S36). Cu electrodes plated with Li were subsequently retrieved from the cycled batteries, regarded as the less Li anodes, which finally were assembled into symmetric batteries or paired with LFP cathodes to fabricate less Li||LFP full batteries. The rate performance and cycling stability of symmetric batteries using Li@Ni-TAA/Cu, Li@Ni-TAP/Cu, and Li@Bare Cu electrodes were first examined at various current densities from 1.0 to 5.0 mA cm–2 with a fixed capacity of 1.0 mA h cm–2 (Figure S37). With the increase of current density, the Li@bare Cu electrodes showed sharply increased overpotentials, and irregular and asymmetric voltage curves could be observed at high current densities (Figure S37a), indicating the cycling instability of symmetric batteries with Li@bare Cu electrodes. In contrast, stable Li plating/stripping processes with significantly decreased voltage hysteresis at various current densities could be achieved when employing Li@Ni-TAA/Cu and Li@Ni-TAP/Cu electrodes (Figure S37b–f). Especially, at the high current of 5.0 mA cm–2, the symmetric batteries with Li@Ni-TAA/Cu and Li@Ni-TAP/Cu electrodes delivered markedly reduced overpotentials of 136 and 151 mV, respectively, suggesting the excellent mass-transfer kinetics (Figure S37f). Moreover, electrochemical resistances and exchange current densities of various symmetric batteries were also tested based on the Nyquist plots and Tafel curves, respectively (Figure S38). Both electrolyte resistances and interfacial resistances of the symmetric batteries with Li@Bare Cu were much higher than those with Li@Ni-TAA/Cu and Li@Ni-TAP/Cu (Figure S38a), indicating that the formed solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) on Li@Ni-TAA/Cu and Li@Ni-TAP/Cu possessed outstanding mass-transfer kinetics, which could also explain why Ni-TAA/Cu and Ni-TAP/Cu exhibited lower mass-transfer overpotentials during Li plating processes. The same conclusion was also drawn by calculating the exchange current densities. The batteries assembled with Li@Ni-TAA/Cu and Li@Ni-TAP/Cu delivered significantly enhanced exchange current densities of 1.055 and 0.849 mA cm–2, respectively, much higher than that of batteries with Li@Bare Cu (i 0 = 0.475 mA cm–2) (Figure S38b), which further suggested that the Ni-TAA and Ni-TAP guiding layers possessed ultrahigh ionic conductivity and enabled fast Li plating/stripping kinetics. The assembly and testing of full batteries proved the practical application potential of Li@Ni-TAA/Cu and Li@Ni-TAP/Cu. As shown in a, significant differences in long-term cycling stability could be observed. The batteries based on Li@Ni-TAA/Cu and Li@Ni-TAP/Cu anodes exhibited markedly extended cycling lifespans and improved CEs, delivering considerable discharge capacities of 140.3 and 122.3 mA h g–1, respectively, even after 400 cycles at 1.0 C. The higher capacity of Ni-TAA@Cu than Ni-TAP@Cu should be attributed to its higher porosity and larger surface area. In sharp contrast, the batteries based on bare Cu with deposited Li anodes experienced rapid capacity decay and suffered from an obvious failure only after 138 cycles, displaying a CE attenuated to zero and an ultralow discharge capacity. It can be convincingly concluded that the huge differences in cycling performance of the less Li||LFP full batteries can be ascribed to the significant differences in surface morphology of various less Li anodes. Benefiting from the superior lithiophilicity and Li-electrodeposition regulating effect of Ni-TAA and Ni-TAP, a uniform and dense surface without any visible dendrites of Li@Ni-TAA/Cu and Li@Ni-TAP/Cu anodes can be achieved (Figure S30), which is greatly conducive to enhancing Li utilization, accelerating Li-ion transfer, and finally ensuring outstanding cycling stability. Furthermore, the rate performance of Li||LFP full batteries assembled with the various anodes was also examined under different current densities from 1.0 to 5.0 C (b). When employing Li@Ni-TAA/Cu and Li@Ni-TAP/Cu as anodes, the batteries showed a boosted rate capability, especially at the high rate of 5.0 C, delivering well-maintained reversible capacities of 126.2 mA h g–1 for Li@Ni-TAA/Cu and 108.5 mA h g–1 for Li@Ni-TAP/Cu. After the current density returned to 1.0 C, the batteries based on Li@Ni-TAP/Cu and Li@Ni-TAP/Cu were still capable of maintaining superior cycling stability, delivering recovered average discharge capacities of 150.1 and 140.8 mA h g–1, respectively. However, for the batteries with Li@Bare Cu, a significant discharge capacity decrease was exhibited with increasing current density, especially at 5.0 C; the discharge capacity decayed to 59.8 mA h g–1. After the current density was reduced to 3.0, 2.0, and 1.0 C again, a substantially fluctuating CE and a continuously attenuated discharge capacity could be observed, indicating the failure of batteries under high current densities. The superior rate performance of Li@Ni-TAA/Cu and Li@Ni-TAP/Cu anodes originated from the lower polarization and better reaction kinetics than the Li@Bare Cu anode, which was confirmed by the smaller potential differences between the charge/discharge plateaus corresponding to Li@Ni-TAA/Cu and Li@Ni-TAP/Cu anodes (c–f).

electrochemical resistances and exchange current densities of various
symmetric batteries were also tested based on the Nyquist plots and
Tafel curves, respectively (Figure S38).
Both electrolyte resistances and interfacial resistances of the symmetric
batteries with Li@Bare Cu were much higher than those with Li@Ni-TAA/Cu
and Li@Ni-TAP/Cu (Figure S38a), indicating
that the formed solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) on Li@Ni-TAA/Cu
and Li@Ni-TAP/Cu possessed outstanding mass-transfer kinetics, which
could also explain why Ni-TAA/Cu and Ni-TAP/Cu exhibited lower mass-transfer
overpotentials during Li plating processes. The same conclusion was
also drawn by calculating the exchange current densities. The batteries
assembled with Li@Ni-TAA/Cu and Li@Ni-TAP/Cu delivered significantly
enhanced exchange current densities of 1.055 and 0.849 mA cm–2, respectively, much higher than that of batteries with Li@Bare Cu
(i
0 = 0.475 mA cm–2)
(Figure S38b), which further suggested
that the Ni-TAA and Ni-TAP guiding layers possessed ultrahigh ionic
conductivity and enabled fast Li plating/stripping kinetics. The assembly
and testing of full batteries proved the practical application potential
of Li@Ni-TAA/Cu and Li@Ni-TAP/Cu. As shown in a, significant differences in long-term cycling
stability could be observed. The batteries based on Li@Ni-TAA/Cu and
Li@Ni-TAP/Cu anodes exhibited markedly extended cycling lifespans
and improved CEs, delivering considerable discharge capacities of
140.3 and 122.3 mA h g–1, respectively, even after
400 cycles at 1.0 C. The higher capacity of Ni-TAA@Cu than Ni-TAP@Cu
should be attributed to its higher porosity and larger surface area.
In sharp contrast, the batteries based on bare Cu with deposited Li
anodes experienced rapid capacity decay and suffered from an obvious
failure only after 138 cycles, displaying a CE attenuated to zero
and an ultralow discharge capacity. It can be convincingly concluded
that the huge differences in cycling performance of the less Li||LFP
full batteries can be ascribed to the significant differences in surface
morphology of various less Li anodes. Benefiting from the superior
lithiophilicity and Li-electrodeposition regulating effect of Ni-TAA
and Ni-TAP, a uniform and dense surface without any visible dendrites
of Li@Ni-TAA/Cu and Li@Ni-TAP/Cu anodes can be achieved (Figure S30), which is greatly conducive to enhancing
Li utilization, accelerating Li-ion transfer, and finally ensuring
outstanding cycling stability. Furthermore, the rate performance of
Li||LFP full batteries assembled with the various anodes was also
examined under different current densities from 1.0 to 5.0 C (b). When employing
Li@Ni-TAA/Cu and Li@Ni-TAP/Cu as anodes, the batteries showed a boosted
rate capability, especially at the high rate of 5.0 C, delivering
well-maintained reversible capacities of 126.2 mA h g–1 for Li@Ni-TAA/Cu and 108.5 mA h g–1 for Li@Ni-TAP/Cu.
After the current density returned to 1.0 C, the batteries based on
Li@Ni-TAP/Cu and Li@Ni-TAP/Cu were still capable of maintaining superior
cycling stability, delivering recovered average discharge capacities
of 150.1 and 140.8 mA h g–1, respectively. However,
for the batteries with Li@Bare Cu, a significant discharge capacity
decrease was exhibited with increasing current density, especially
at 5.0 C; the discharge capacity decayed to 59.8 mA h g–1. After the current density was reduced to 3.0, 2.0, and 1.0 C again,
a substantially fluctuating CE and a continuously attenuated discharge
capacity could be observed, indicating the failure of batteries under
high current densities. The superior rate performance of Li@Ni-TAA/Cu
and Li@Ni-TAP/Cu anodes originated from the lower polarization and
better reaction kinetics than the Li@Bare Cu anode, which was confirmed
by the smaller potential differences between the charge/discharge
plateaus corresponding to Li@Ni-TAA/Cu and Li@Ni-TAP/Cu anodes (c–f).

elements.content: In summary, two novel COFs based on a Ni–bis­(dithiolene) have been successfully constructed. As an inorganic analogue of TTF-TBA, Ni­(bded)2 stands out as a promising building unit to make functional COFs with conductivity and electrochemical activity. As a proof of concept, introducing Ni­(bded)2 into Ni-TAP and Ni-TAA has demonstrated excellent performance in significantly improving the lithiophilicity and electric conductivity of Cu current collectors. Hence, the Li||Cu half cells based on Ni-TAA/Cu and Ni-TAP/Cu showed obviously enhanced Li utilization and cycling stability. When paired with LFP cathodes to form full batteries, both Li@Ni-TAA/Cu and Li@Ni-TAP/Cu presented prominently improved Li plating/stripping stability and impressive rate capability. This work demonstrates the first example of the Ni–bis­(dithiolene)-based COF and its applications in LMBs, which opens promising prospects for designing novel electrochemically active COFs with a wide range of applications. Considering the diverse functions of metal–bis­(dithiolene) units, future applications of metal–bis­(dithiolene)-based COFs can be envisioned in the fields of catalysis, electrochemistry, magnetics, optics, and beyond.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions
In
summary, two novel COFs based on a Ni–bis­(dithiolene)
have been successfully constructed. As an inorganic analogue of TTF-TBA,
Ni­(bded)2 stands out as a promising building unit to make
functional COFs with conductivity and electrochemical activity. As
a proof of concept, introducing Ni­(bded)2 into Ni-TAP and
Ni-TAA has demonstrated excellent performance in significantly improving
the lithiophilicity and electric conductivity of Cu current collectors.
Hence, the Li||Cu half cells based on Ni-TAA/Cu and Ni-TAP/Cu showed
obviously enhanced Li utilization and cycling stability. When paired
with LFP cathodes to form full batteries, both Li@Ni-TAA/Cu and Li@Ni-TAP/Cu
presented prominently improved Li plating/stripping stability and
impressive rate capability. This work demonstrates the first example
of the Ni–bis­(dithiolene)-based COF and its applications in
LMBs, which opens promising prospects for designing novel electrochemically
active COFs with a wide range of applications. Considering the diverse
functions of metal–bis­(dithiolene) units, future applications
of metal–bis­(dithiolene)-based COFs can be envisioned in the
fields of catalysis, electrochemistry, magnetics, optics, and beyond.

elements.content: Ni­(bded)2 (13.1 mg, 0.02 mmol) and 2,3,6,7-tetra­(4-aminophenyl)­pyrene (12.6 mg, 0.02 mmol) were charged into a 10 mL Pyrex tube. Then, a mixture of n-BuOH 6 M HOAc (1.2 mL, 1/0.2 by vol) was added to the tube, and the mixture was sonicated for 10 min. The resulting mixture was degassed by freeze–pump–thaw cycles and sealed under vacuum. The sealed tube was heated at 120 °C for 3 days. The solid was collected by centrifugation and washed with methanol and THF. Ni-TAP was then washed with THF in a Soxhlet extractor overnight. The resulting powder was dried at 100 °C under vacuum to yield Ni-TAP (16.7 mg, 65% yield).

Experimental Section
Synthesis of Ni-TAP
Ni­(bded)2 (13.1 mg,
0.02 mmol) and 2,3,6,7-tetra­(4-aminophenyl)­pyrene (12.6 mg, 0.02 mmol)
were charged into a 10 mL Pyrex tube. Then, a mixture of n-BuOH 6 M HOAc (1.2 mL, 1/0.2 by vol) was added to the tube, and
the mixture was sonicated for 10 min. The resulting mixture was degassed
by freeze–pump–thaw cycles and sealed under vacuum.
The sealed tube was heated at 120 °C for 3 days. The solid was
collected by centrifugation and washed with methanol and THF. Ni-TAP
was then washed with THF in a Soxhlet extractor overnight. The resulting
powder was dried at 100 °C under vacuum to yield Ni-TAP (16.7
mg, 65% yield).

Then, a mixture of o-DCB/n-BuOH/6 M HOAc (1.2 mL, 0.2/0.8/0.2 by vol.) was added to the tube, and the mixture was sonicated for 10 min. The resulting mixture was degassed by freeze–pump–thaw cycles and sealed under vacuum. The sealed tube was heated at 120 °C for 3 days. The resulting powder was dried at 100 °C under vacuum to yield Ni-TAA (10.9 mg, 68% yield).

Synthesis of Ni-TAA
Ni­(bded)2 (9.8 mg, 0.015
mmol) and 2,4,6-tris­(4-aminophenyl)­amine (6.3 mg, 0.02 mmol) were
charged into a 10 mL Pyrex tube. Then, a mixture of o-DCB/n-BuOH/6 M HOAc (1.2 mL, 0.2/0.8/0.2 by vol.)
was added to the tube, and the mixture was sonicated for 10 min. The
resulting mixture was degassed by freeze–pump–thaw cycles

elements.content: Ni-TAA or Ni-TAP powder (80 wt %) and polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF, 20 wt %) were mixed in N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP). After magnetic stirring for 24 h, a homogeneous slurry was obtained. Ni-TAA/Cu (or Ni-TAP/Cu) was prepared by tape casting the slurry on bare Cu foils using a scraper with a controllable thickness. Then, the solvent was removed by drying at 80 °C for 12 h. The as-obtained electrode materials were cut into small disks with a mass loading of 0.75–0.80 mg cm–2 and a diameter of 13 mm for coin cell assembly.
elements.clean_text:
Preparation of Ni-TAA/Cu
and Ni-TAP/Cu
Ni-TAA or Ni-TAP
powder (80 wt %) and polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF, 20 wt %) were
mixed in N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP). After magnetic
stirring for 24 h, a homogeneous slurry was obtained. Ni-TAA/Cu (or
Ni-TAP/Cu) was prepared by tape casting the slurry on bare Cu foils
using a scraper with a controllable thickness. Then, the solvent was
removed by drying at 80 °C for 12 h. The as-obtained electrode
materials were cut into small disks with a mass loading of 0.75–0.80
mg cm–2 and a diameter of 13 mm for coin cell assembly.

processes.material mix: Ni-TAA or Ni-TAP powder (80 wt %) and polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF, 20 wt %)

elements.content: To evaluate the Li plating/stripping stability, 2032-type coin cells were assembled with various Cu-plated Li electrodes in a symmetric configuration. Less Li||LFP full batteries were assembled with various Cu plated Li electrodes as anodes and LFP as a cathode. The electrolyte used for both symmetric and full cells is 1.0 M lithium hexafluorophosphate (LiPF6) dissolved in ethylene carbonate/dimethyl carbonate/ethyl methyl carbonate (EC/DEC, a volume ratio of 1:1). The voltage window for testing of the LFP cathode was set to 2.6–4.2 V. All coin cells were galvanostatically cycled on a LAND-CT2001 8-channel battery tester. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) of Li||Cu half cells and Li||Li symmetric batteries were conducted in the frequency range from 100 kHz to 10 mHz. Tafel plots and exchange current densities (i 0) were tested based on Li||Li symmetric batteries at a scan rate of 5.0 mV s–1 from −0.18 to 0.18 V. CV of Li||Cu half cells was carried out at a scan rate of 5.0 mV s–1 from −0.4 to 0.8 V and 0.5 mV s–1 from 0 to 2.5 V. Both EIS and CV were performed on a Chenhua CHI-760 electrochemical workstation. The GITT tests were carried out at 20 mA g–1 for 30 min, followed by a rest time of 2 h to reach the steady-state voltage.

To evaluate
the Li plating/stripping stability, 2032-type coin cells were assembled
with various Cu-plated Li electrodes in a symmetric configuration.
Less Li||LFP full batteries were assembled with various Cu plated
Li electrodes as anodes and LFP as a cathode. The electrolyte used
for both symmetric and full cells is 1.0 M lithium hexafluorophosphate
(LiPF6) dissolved in ethylene carbonate/dimethyl carbonate/ethyl
methyl carbonate (EC/DEC, a volume ratio of 1:1). The voltage window
for testing of the LFP cathode was set to 2.6–4.2 V. All coin
cells were galvanostatically cycled on a LAND-CT2001 8-channel battery
tester. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) of Li||Cu half
cells and Li||Li symmetric batteries were conducted in the frequency
range from 100 kHz to 10 mHz. Tafel plots and exchange current densities
(i
0) were tested based on Li||Li symmetric
batteries at a scan rate of 5.0 mV s–1 from −0.18
to 0.18 V. CV of Li||Cu half cells was carried out at a scan rate
of 5.0 mV s–1 from −0.4 to 0.8 V and 0.5
mV s–1 from 0 to 2.5 V. Both EIS and CV were performed
on a Chenhua CHI-760 electrochemical workstation. The GITT tests were
carried out at 20 mA g–1 for 30 min, followed by
a rest time of 2 h to reach the steady-state voltage.
